notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: Enrolment Controls removed: July 11, 2018; Room Change: August 22, 2018

cmCourseInfo.description: This course is designed for students with no prior knowledge of Arabic. It places equal emphasis on the development of all language skills: reading, writing, listening, and speaking. The learning philosophy underlying this approach is that proficiency in a foreign language is best achieved through consistent, deliberate, and systematic practice. From the outset, students are strongly encouraged to develop the habit of consistently practicing learned material.
cmCourseInfo.title: Elementary Standard Arabic
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: Priority enrollment will be given to declared NMC majors/specialists.

cmCourseInfo.description: See MHB155H1 in Religion.
cmCourseInfo.title: Elementary Modern Hebrew I

cmCourseInfo.description: See MHB156H1 in Religion.
cmCourseInfo.title: Elementary Modern Hebrew II

cmCourseInfo.description: This course assumes active knowledge of the content covered in NML110Y.  It places equal emphasis on the development of all language skills.  As the course progresses, students are introduced to the fundamentals of Arabic morphology and syntax.  This is achieved through analysis of texts covering a wide range of topics.  By the end of the course, students are expected to achieve upper intermediate level of proficiency.
cmCourseInfo.title: Intermediate Standard Arabic I (formerly NML211Y)
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: NML110Y1 or permission of the instructor.
cmCourseInfo.exclusionsText: Native speaker. Priority enrollment will be given to declared NMC majors/specialists.

cmCourseInfo.description: Introduces the student to the last stage of the Egyptian language, written mostly in Greek characters. The course will first concentrate on the grammar of the language and go on to read short texts.
cmCourseInfo.title: Elementary Coptic I

cmCourseInfo.description: A continuation of NML230H1.
cmCourseInfo.title: Elementary Coptic II

cmCourseInfo.description: Grammar and reading of selected hieroglyphic texts.
cmCourseInfo.title: Introduction to Middle Egyptian

cmCourseInfo.description: An introduction to biblical Hebrew prose. Grammar and selected texts. For students with no previous knowledge of Hebrew.
cmCourseInfo.title: Introductory Biblical Hebrew
cmCourseInfo.exclusionsText: Those who have completed Grade 8 Hebrew (or Grade 6 in Israel)

cmCourseInfo.description: See MHB255H1 in Religion.
cmCourseInfo.title: Intermediate Modern Hebrew I
cmCourseInfo.exclusionsText: Those who have completed Grade 8 Hebrew (or Ulpan level 2 in Israel), MHB255H1

cmCourseInfo.description: See MHB256H1 in Religion.
cmCourseInfo.title: Intermediate Modern Hebrew II
cmCourseInfo.exclusionsText: Those who have completed Grade 8 Hebrew (or Ulpan level 2 in Israel), MHB256H1

cmCourseInfo.description: The fundamentals of modern standard Persian grammar, with emphasis on attaining fluency in reading and writing simple texts. Also serves as a basis for classical Persian. (Offered in alternate years)
cmCourseInfo.title: Introductory Persian
cmCourseInfo.exclusionsText: Native users. Priority enrollment will be given to declared NMC majors/specialists

cmCourseInfo.description: This course covers the essentials of Turkish grammar, and introduces students to reading and translation of passages of elementary difficulty. Designed for students with no previous knowledge of Turkish. This course also serves as a basis for the study of Ottoman Turkish and other Turkic languages.
cmCourseInfo.title: Introductory Turkish

cmCourseInfo.description: Introduction to Old Babylonian. Grammar and the reading of selected texts. (Offered in alternate years)
cmCourseInfo.title: Introductory Akkadian

cmCourseInfo.description: This course assumes active knowledge of the content covered in NML210Y.  As the course progresses, students are introduced to increasingly complex morphological and syntactic patterns of Arabic. This is achieved through analysis of texts covering a wide range of genres. By the end of the course, students are expected to achieve advanced level of proficiency.
cmCourseInfo.title: Intermediate Standard Arabic II
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: NML210Y1 or permission of the instructor.
cmCourseInfo.exclusionsText: Native speakers. Priority enrollment will be given to declared NMC majors/specialists.

cmCourseInfo.description: An intensive study of various Targumim to the Pentateuch: Onkelos, Pseudo-Jonathan, Neophyti, Samaritan and Fragment Targumim. Differences among them in vocabulary, syntax and verb usage are discussed, as well as their relationship to the Palestinian midrashim. (Offered in alternate years)
cmCourseInfo.title: Intermediate Aramaic: Targum

cmCourseInfo.description: Middle Egyptian texts.
cmCourseInfo.title: Intermediate Egyptian

cmCourseInfo.description: See MHB355H1 in Religion.
cmCourseInfo.title: Advanced Modern Hebrew I

cmCourseInfo.description: See MHB356H1 in Religion.
cmCourseInfo.title: Advanced Modern Hebrew II

cmCourseInfo.description: This course will survey the grammar and religious concepts found within the Book Pahlavi or Zoroastrian Middle Persian corpus from late antique and early Islamic Iran. By the end of the year students will have acquired a strong understanding of the script, grammar, and syntax of the Pahlavi corpus. Some knowledge of Persian is an advantage.
cmCourseInfo.title: Middle Persian (Pahlavi)
cmCourseInfo.recommendedPreparation:
NML260Y1 or NML262Y1

Breadth Requirements: Creative and Cultural Representations (1)

Distribution Requirements: Humanities

cmCourseInfo.description: This course will survey the grammar and religious concepts found within the Book Pahlavi or Zoroastrian Middle Persian corpus from late antique and early Islamic Iran. By the end of the year students will have acquired a strong understanding of the script, grammar, and syntax of the Pahlavi corpus. Some knowledge of Persian is an advantage.
cmCourseInfo.title: Middle Persian (Pahlavi)
cmCourseInfo.recommendedPreparation:
NML260Y1 or NML262Y1

Breadth Requirements: Creative and Cultural Representations (1)

Distribution Requirements: Humanities

cmCourseInfo.description: This course involves reading, grammatical analysis and translation of modern Turkish texts of intermediate difficulty. The reading materials are selected from a wise range of literary genres. Included is a basic review of grammar as well as more advanced grammatical topics. Course serves as preparation for advanced study of Turkish as well as study of Ottoman Turksih language and literature.
cmCourseInfo.title: Intermediate Turkish

cmCourseInfo.description: This course covers the essentials of Ge'ez (Classical Ethiopic) grammar, and introduces students to Ge'ez texts of elementary to intermediate difficulty. Designed for students with no previous knowledge of Ge'ez.
cmCourseInfo.title: Introduction to Ge'ez (Classical Ethiopic)

cmCourseInfo.description: This course continues the study of Ge'ez (Classical Ethiopic) grammar and progresses to a survey of classical Ge’ez literature. Linguistic connections to Amharic and Tigrinye will also be introduced.
cmCourseInfo.title: Intermediate Ge'ez

cmCourseInfo.description: This course assumes active knowledge of the content covered in NML310Y.  Its goal is to strengthen the students reading and writing skills, refine their knowledge of syntax and morphological patterns, and enrich their cultural background. This is achieved through analysis of sophisticated authentic texts covering a wide range of genres. In addition, Classical Arabic literary texts will be incrementally introduced.  By the end of the course, students are expected to reach a superior level of proficiency.
cmCourseInfo.title: Advanced Standard Arabic

cmCourseInfo.description: Every week we read a poem by a new poet, focusing on the most famous and frequently quoted poems of the pre-modern Arabic literary tradition. Students learn how to identify meters and recognize the rhetorical tropes described by Arabic rhetoric. Poets include: Labīd, Abū Nuwās, Abū Tammām, and al-Mutanabbī.
cmCourseInfo.title: Premodern Arabic Poetry
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: NML310Y1 (third-year Arabic) or permission of the instructor. Heritage speakers are encouraged to take this class, and should seek permission of the instructor.

courses.name: The Jerusalem Talmud: Jewish Western Aramaic

cmCourseInfo.description: The Talmud of the Land of Israel, also called Talmud Yerushalmi or Palestinian Talmud, is written in a mixture of Jewish Western Aramaic and Mishnaic Hebrew. It is the principal document of the Land of Israel in Late Antiquity. The course examines the legal argumentation, terminology and language which differ from those of the Babylonian Talmud. (Offered in alternate years)
cmCourseInfo.title: The Jerusalem Talmud: Jewish Western Aramaic

cmCourseInfo.description: A study of the poetic works of a major modern Hebrew poet. (Conducted in Hebrew) (Offered in alternate years)
cmCourseInfo.title: Modern Hebrew Poetry

cmCourseInfo.description: A study of the poetic works of a major modern Hebrew poet. (Conducted in Hebrew) (Offered in alternate years)
cmCourseInfo.title: Modern Hebrew Poetry

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
This course is designed for the advanced student of Modern Hebrew (minimum level – completion of Intermediate Hebrew) who wishes to pursue the study of Hebrew Literature. We will proceed in progressive steps from an exploration of children’s poetry (and stories) by great modern poets and others. We will examine the way in which this literature relates to ideas of land, homeland, kibbutz identity, peoplehood, and religious identities. We will continue with Yehuda Amihai’s love poetry and conclude with Ḥaim Naḥman Bialik’s love poetry.

courses.name: Theory and Practice of Translation from and into Persian

cmCourseInfo.description: An introduction to theories and techniques involves in English/Persian translation, focusing on translation practice and theoretical discussions on linguistic, cognitive, socio-political, and cultural aspects of translation. Through analysis and application of translation theory, students practice the art of translation and develop awareness of issues that translators face.
cmCourseInfo.title: Theory and Practice of Translation from and into Persian

cmCourseInfo.description: Explores iconic masterpieces of classical Persian heroic and romantic epic poetry, including the Persian national epic, Shahnameh, of Ferdowsi; the magisterial odes of Khaqani; and the Khamseh, or Quintet, of Nezami and its many literary responses. Emphasizes close reading and analysis of the texts and their historical and cultural backgrounds.
cmCourseInfo.title: Persian Literature: The Epic Tradition
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: NML360Y1 or adequate knowledge of Persian

courses.name: Persian Literature: Ethical, Erotic, and Mystical

cmCourseInfo.description: Explores the ethical works of Sa‘di (Bustan and Gulistan); the mystical Mantiq al-Tayr of ‘Attar and the Masnavi of Rumi; and the ghazals, or mystico-erotic poems, of Rumi and Hafiz. Emphasizes close reading and analysis of the texts and their historical, cultural, and religious backgrounds.
cmCourseInfo.title: Persian Literature: Ethical, Erotic, and Mystical
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: NML360Y1 or adequate knowledge of Persian

cmCourseInfo.description: Advanced Turkish language practice designed to enable students to pursue independent work in Turkish and Ottoman studies. Differences between modern Turkish and Ottoman grammar will be pointed out. Elements of Arabic and Persian grammar that occur in Ottoman will be presented.
cmCourseInfo.title: Advanced Turkish
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: NML370Y1 or adequate knowledge of Turkish

courses.name: Select Topics in Near and Middle Eastern Languages

sections.name: LEC0201
sections.subTitle: Readings in Arabic from the Age of the Crusades

cmCourseInfo.description: An advanced language seminar organized around grammatical issues or texts selected by the instructor.
cmCourseInfo.title: Select Topics in Near and Middle Eastern Languages
